facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 167 of 1961 in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 29, and October 11, 1961, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 906 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 29, and October 11, 1961, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 906 of 1961. G. Patwardhan, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder

facts.text: The appellant was tried by the Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Esplanade, Bombay for offences under ss. 3, 2 and 4, 1 of the Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 104 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was tried by the Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Esplanade, Bombay for offences under ss. 3 2  and 4 1  of the Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act  Act 104 of 1956  hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Appellant acquitted by the Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was tried for the offences above mentioned but was acquitted by the Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate.

facts.text: Bombay High Court set aside the order of acquittal and sentenced the appellant to one year's rigorous imprisonment and ordered her eviction from the premises.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 29, and October 11, 1961, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 906 of 1961.

facts.text: Premises at block No. 6, plot No. 144 Shivaji Park, Bombay occupied by appellant as tenant and used as brothel.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against the appellant was that she supplied a girl to Manmohan Anandji Mehta who is a witness and she kept or managed a brothel at block No. 6, plot No. 144 Shivaji Park, Bombay

facts.text: Police Superintendent Kanga received information that the premises were being used as a brothel and appellant supplying girls for prostitution.

anchor.surface_text: The story of the prosecution was that information was received by Police Superintendent Kanga that the premises were being used as a brothel and that the appellant was supplying girls for the purpose of prostitution.

facts.text: Superintendent Kanga laid a trap and sent Manmohan Anandji Mehta and Prabhakar K. Loke to appellant's house.

anchor.surface_text: He thereupon laid a trap and sent two persons, Manmohan Anandji Mehta and Prabhakar K. Loke, the former was to ask for a girl for the purpose of prostitution and the latter was to be a panch i. e. a witness of that fact.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector Purohit gave two one hundred rupees marked currency notes to Manmohan Anandji Mehta.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-Inspector Purohit, it is stated, gave two one hundred rupees marked currency numberes to Manmohan Anandji Mehta with the instruction that he was to pay out of that to the appellant

facts.text: Manmohan Anandji Mehta and Loke went to the house of the appellant, rang the bell and were admitted by her.

anchor.surface_text: He along with Loke went to the house of the appellant, rang the bell and was admitted by her. He then asked the appellant to arrange a girl for him

facts.text: Manmohan Anandji Mehta asked appellant to arrange a girl for prostitution and both wanted two girls for enjoyment.

anchor.surface_text: He then asked the appellant to arrange a girl for him and both Manmohan Anandji Mehta and Loke are alleged to have said that they wanted two girls for enjoyment.

facts.text: Two girls shown: Kamal Govind (Rs. 100) and Indu Bapurao Salunke (Rs. 50).

anchor.surface_text: Two girls were shown, one Kamal Govind and the other Indu Bapurao Salunke both of whom are witnesses. The amount quoted by the appellant in the case of the former was Rs. 100/-and for the latter Rs. 50/-

facts.text: Manmohan Anandji Mehta selected Kamal Govind and handed one hundred rupees marked currency note to the appellant who put it under her blouse.

anchor.surface_text: Manmohan Anandji Mehta selected Kamal and handed over heroine one hundred rupees currency numbere to the appellant which she put under her blouse.

facts.text: Manmohan Anandji Mehta and Kamal Govind went into the kitchen, undressed, found naked in compromising position.

anchor.surface_text: Manmohan Anandji Mehta and the girl then went into the kitchen and there they undressed and were later found naked on the floor and in a rather companypromising position.

facts.text: On signal, Superintendent Kanga and Sub-Inspector Purohit entered, found Mehta and Kamal naked in kitchen.

anchor.surface_text: On a signal being given the police i.e. Superintendent Kanga and Sub-Inspector Purohit entered the premises and were told by Loke that Manmohan Anandji Mehta and the girl were in the kitchen.

facts.text: Manmohan Anandji Mehta returned the other one hundred rupees marked currency note to Superintendent Kanga.

anchor.surface_text: Manmohan Anandji Mehta then returned the other one hundred rupees currency numbere to superintendent Kanga.

facts.text: Woman Panch searched appellant and recovered the one hundred rupees marked currency note from under her blouse.

anchor.surface_text: A woman Panch who had accompanied the police party searched the appellant and recovered the one hundred rupees currency numbere from under the blouse.

facts.text: Male members were in a passage adjoining the hall during the search of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated that the male members of the party were at that time in a passage adjoining the hall where the appellant was searched.

facts.text: High Court accepted testimony of Loke regarding payment of hundred rupees to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has, accepted the testimony of Loke and we find numberreason to depart from the usual practice of this Court, of accepting such findings.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on January 18, 1962 by KAPUR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 18.-The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds High Court conviction of appellant under s.3 of the Act and eviction order under s.18.

anchor.surface_text: On the findings of the High Court we are unable to companye to any other companyclusion but the one to which the High Court came that the appellant is guilty of the offences of which she was accused.

facts.text: Woman panch who searched appellant not produced in court.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant emphasised two points  1  that the woman, who was brought by the police to search the appellant and is alleged to have recovered the hundred rupees numbere from her person, has number been produced

facts.text: Appellant contended that search of woman should not be in presence of men.

anchor.surface_text: and  2  that companysidering that the person to be searched was a woman it must be presumed that in accordance with the requirements of law and of decency numberman companyld have been present when the search of the appellant took place.

facts.text: Evidence of Police Superintendent Kanga and Sub-Inspector Purohit corroborates finding Mehta and Kamal naked.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of Police Superintendent Kanga shows that when the door of the kitchen was pushed open both Kamal and Manmohan Anandji Mehta were naked and were in a companypromising position their clothes were lying by the side of the mattress,

anchor.surface_text: The next submission of Counsel for the appellant was that the High Court in appeal could not order the appellants eviction because that power only a Magistrate has under s. 18 of the Act. The argument raised was that the powers of the appeal court under s. 423, Criminal Procedure Code are to reverse the order of acquittal or to order a fresh enquiry or a retrial etc. but not to order eviction. But this argument is untenable in view of the fact that in the Act there is a specific provision in s. 18 of the Act authorising the making of such an order by a court convicting a person of offences under s. 3 or s. 7 of the Act. The relevant portion of s. 18 is as follows- S. 18 Closure of brothels and eviction of offenders from the premises,-  1  ,and if after hearing the person concerned, the magistrate is satisfied that the houseor portion is being used as a brothel or for carrying on prostitution then the magistrate may pass orders-  a  directing eviction of the occupier within seven days of the passing of the order from the house A court convicting a person of any offence under section 3 or section 7 may pass orders under sub-section  1  without further notice to such person to show cause as required in that sub-section.

concepts.interpretation: Appellate court convicting under s.3 or s.7 can order eviction without further notice

issues.text: Whether the appellant is guilty of the offences under sections 3, 2 and 4(1) of the Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 1956?

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was tried by the Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Esplanade, Bombay for offences under ss. 3 2  and 4 1  of the Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act  Act 104 of 1956  hereinafter called the Act. The charge against the appellant was that she supplied a girl to Manmohan Anandji Mehta who is a witness and she kept or managed a brothel at block No. 6, plot No. 144 Shivaji Park, Bombay that she knowingly lived on the earnings of prostitution and that the procured women for the purpose of prostitution.

issues.text: Whether the evidence regarding the recovery of the marked currency note from the appellant is reliable, given that the woman panch was not produced as a witness and men may have been present during the search, violating requirements under ss.52 and 103 CrPC?

anchor.surface_text: But it was submitted on behalf of the appellant that this evidence should number be accepted as, according to law, numberwoman can be searched except by another woman and having regard to the emphasis on decency under ss. 52 and 103 of the Criminal Procedure Code that cannot be done in the presence of men. There is numberevidence to show except that of Manmohan Anandji Mehta that the men were asked to move away from the hall or had actually left the hall during the search. But assuming they were number in the hall even then it will number be an extraordinary circum- stance that one or all of them should have seen the hundred rupees, numbere being taken out from under the blouse of the appellant.

issues.text: Whether the reprehensible police trap method involving sending decoy witnesses to engage in prostitution vitiates the conviction despite judicial disapproval?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant emphasised two points  1  that the woman, who was brought by the police to search the appellant and is alleged to have recovered the hundred rupees numbere from her person, has number been produced and  2  that companysidering that the person to be searched was a woman it must be presumed that in accordance with the requirements of law and of decency numberman companyld have been present when the search of the appellant took place. In support of the first companytention reference is made to a judgment of this, Court in Purvez Ardeshir Poonawalla v. The State of Bombay 1 , where the necessity of producing the search witness was emphasised and it was observed- This is, one of those cases where the rule in regard to search witnesses becomes applicable and importance must be attached to the lack of that class, of search witnesses which are envisaged by the Criminal Procedure Code in s. 103.

issues.text: Whether the High Court, as an appellate court, had the power to order the eviction of the appellant under section 18 of the SITA upon convicting her under section 3?

The argument raised was that the powers of the appeal companyrt under s. 423, Criminal Procedure Code are to reverse the order of acquittal or to order a fresh enquiry or a retrial etc. but number to order eviction. But this argument is untenable in view of the fact that in the Act there is a specific provision in s. 18 of the Act authorising the making of such an order by a companyrt companyvicting a person of offences under s. 3 or s. 7 of the Act.

holdings.text: On the findings of the High Court we are unable to come to any other conclusion but the one to which the High Court came that the appellant is guilty of the offences of which she was accused.

anchor.surface_text: On the findings of the High Court we are unable to companye to any other companyclusion but the one to which the High Court came that the appellant is guilty of the offences of which she was accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defers to High Court's acceptance of witness testimonies (Loke, Mehta, police) and factual findings on payment, supply of girl for prostitution, and brothel management, corroborated by circumstances.

holdings.text: The High Court has accepted the testimony of Loke in regard to the payment of a hundred rupees currency note to the appellant which proves that money was paid before the girl, Kamal Govind, was asked to go with Manmohan Anandji Mehta for the purpose of prostitution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has, accepted the testimony of Loke and we find numberreason to depart from the usual practice of this Court, of accepting such findings. Besides, the High Court has also accepted the testimony of Loke in regard to the payment of a hundred rupees currency numbere to the appellant which proves that money was paid before the girl, Kamal Govind, was asked to go with Manmohan Anandji Mehta for the purpose of prostitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court credibility findings accepted per usual Supreme Court practice; payment proved independently of recovery evidence; precedents on search witnesses distinguished as not directly applicable.

holdings.text: The payment must therefore be held to be proved. It may be that the search was contrary to the spirit or even the letter of the Criminal Procedure Code but the fact remains that the High Court has accepted that there was a search and a hundred rupees currency note was recovered and even if the recovery of a hundred rupees currency note were held not proved, the payment of that amount will not thereby become unproved if there is evidence which the High Court has accepted.

anchor.surface_text: After saving this we have still to see what is the companysequence of the testimoney of these witness produced in this case. The High Court has believed the testimony of Loke in regard to the payment of one hundred rupees and there is evidence to show that amount was used for the purpose of procuring Kamla for prostitution. The payment must therefore be held to be proved. It may be that the search was companytrary to the spirit or even the letter of the Criminal Procedure Code but the fact remains that the High Court has accepted that there was a search and a hundred rupees currency numbere was recovered and even if the recovery of a hundred rupees currency numbere were held number proved, the payment of that amount will number thereby become unproved if there evidence which the High Court has accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of search witness or procedural irregularities in search do not vitiate proof of payment where corroborated by accepted testimony; recovery secondary to direct evidence of transaction.

holdings.text: If in any case the following observations of Lord Goddard, Chief Justice, in Brannan v. Peek are apposite it is this case... We have only to substitute the words aid an act of prostitution for to commit an offence and the analogy is complete... After saying this we have still to see what is the consequence of the testimony of these witness produced in this case. The High Court has believed the testimony... The payment must therefore be held to be proved.

anchor.surface_text: The observations in Poonawallas case 1 and Lord Porter in Malikkhan v. Emperor 2 are number directly applicable in the present case. As we have said above there is evidence in this case which has been accepted by the High Court that a hundred rupees numbere was given to the appellant by Manmohan Anandji Mehta. There is also evidence that as a companysequence of the payment of money Manmohan Anandji Mehta did hire Kamal Govind for prostitution and it is regrettable to say that with the money given to him by the police he acted number merely as a bogus customer, as he has been described, but his participation was more active, reprehensible, immodest, indecent and indecorous. If in any case the following observations of Lord Goddard, Chief Justice, in Brannan, v. Peek 3 are apposite it is this case The companyrt observes with companycern and disapproval the fact that the police authority as Derby thought it right to send a police officer into a public house to companymit an offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Police method of using decoys to induce prostitution disapproved as reprehensible, but does not vitiate conviction where testimony proves offence independently.

holdings.text: But this argument is untenable in view of the fact that in the Act there is a specific provision in s. 18 of the Act authorising the making of such an order by a court convicting a person of offences under s. 3 or s. 7 of the Act... The High Court ordered the conviction of the appellant under s. 3 of the Act and therefore it had the power to order her eviction.

anchor.surface_text: But this argument is untenable in view of the fact that in the Act there is a specific provision in s. 18 of the Act authorising the making of such an order by a companyrt companyvicting a person of offences under s. 3 or s. 7 of the Act. The relevant portion of s. 18 is as follows- S. 18 Closure of brothels and eviction of offenders from the premises,- 1 ,and if after hearing the person companycerned, the magistrate is satisfied that the houseor portion is being used as a brothel or for carrying on prostitution then the magistrate may pass orders- a directing eviction of the occupier within seven days of the passing of the order from the house A companyrt companyvicting a person of any offence under section 3 or section 7 may pass orders under sub-section 1 without further numberice to such person to show cause as required in that sub-section. The High Court ordered the companyviction of the appellant under s. 3 of the Act and therefore it had the power to order her eviction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18(2) explicitly empowers any convicting court (not just magistrate) to order eviction without notice upon conviction under s.3 or s.7, prevailing over general CrPC appellate powers in s.423.

holdings.text: The observations in Poonawallas case and Lord Porter in Malak Khan v. Emperor are not directly applicable in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council also in Malak Khan v. Emperor 2 emphasised the necessity of the presence of search witnesses. Lord Porter there said In their Lordships opinion the presence of witnesses, at a search is always desirable and their absence will weaken and may sometimes destroy the acceptance of the evidence as, to the finding of the articles The observations in Poonawallas case 1 and Lord Porter in Malikkhan v. Emperor 2 are number directly applicable in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents requiring production of search witnesses apply to cases dependent on recovery evidence; here payment proved by independent accepted testimony.

precedents.citation: Purvez Ardeshir Poonawalla v. The State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Purvez Ardeshir Poonawalla v. The State of Bombay 1

precedents.case_name: Purvez Ardeshir Poonawalla v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: necessity of producing the search witness and importance must be attached to the lack of search witnesses under s. 103 CrPC
precedents.cited_holding: This is, one of those cases where the rule in regard to search witnesses becomes applicable and importance must be attached to the lack of that class, of search witnesses which are envisaged by the Criminal Procedure Code in s. 103.

anchor.surface_text: Malak Khan v. Emperor 2

precedents.cited_proposition: presence of witnesses at a search is always desirable and their absence will weaken the evidence
precedents.cited_holding: In their Lordships opinion the presence of witnesses, at a search is always desirable and their absence will weaken and may sometimes destroy the acceptance of the evidence as, to the finding of the articles

anchor.surface_text: Brannan, v. Peek 3

precedents.cited_proposition: it is wholly wrong for police to send a person to commit an offence to detect offence by another
precedents.cited_holding: The court observes with concern and disapproval the fact that the police authority as Derby thought it right to send a police officer into a public house to commit an offence. It cannot be too strongly emphasised that,it is wholly wrong for a police officer or any other person to be sent to commit an offence in order that an offence by another person may be detected.

anchor.surface_text: On the findings of the High Court we are unable to companye to any other companyclusion but the one to which the High Court came that the appellant is guilty of the offences of which she was accused. The next submission of Counsel for the appellant was that the High Court in appeal companyld number order the appellants eviction because that power only a Magistrate has under s. 18 of the Act. The argument raised was that the powers of the appeal companyrt under s. 423, Criminal Procedure Code are to reverse the order of acquittal or to order a fresh enquiry or a retrial etc. but number to order eviction. But this argument is untenable in view of the fact that in the Act there is a specific provision in s. 18 of the Act authorising the making of such an order by a companyrt companyvicting a person of offences under s. 3 or s. 7 of the Act.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court's order setting aside acquittal, convicting appellant under Section 3 of the Act, sentencing to one year rigorous imprisonment, and ordering eviction upheld; all contentions of appellant rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has, accepted the testimony of Loke and we find numberreason to depart from the usual practice of this Court, of accepting such findings. Besides, the High Court has also accepted the testimony of Loke in regard to the payment of a hundred rupees currency numbere to the appellant which proves that money was paid before the girl, Kamal Govind, was asked to go with Manmohan Anandji Mehta for the purpose of prostitution.

On the findings of the High Court we are unable to companye to any other companyclusion but the one to which the High Court came that the appellant is guilty of the offences of which she was accused. But this argument is untenable in view of the fact that in the Act there is a specific provision in s. 18 of the Act authorising the making of such an order by a companyrt companyvicting a person of offences under s. 3 or s. 7 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: After saving this we have still to see what is the companysequence of the testimoney of these witness produced in this case. The High Court has believed the testimony of Loke in regard to the payment of one hundred rupees and there is evidence to show that amount was used for the purpose of procuring Kamla for prostitution. The payment must therefore be held to be proved. It may be that the search was companytrary to the spirit or even the letter of the Criminal Procedure Code but the fact remains that the High Court has accepted that there was a search and a hundred rupees currency numbere was recovered and even if the recovery of a hundred rupees currency numbere were held number proved, the payment of that amount will number thereby become unproved if there evidence which the High Court has accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The observations in Poonawallas case 1 and Lord Porter in Malikkhan v. Emperor 2 are number directly applicable in the present case. As we have said above there is evidence in this case which has been accepted by the High Court that a hundred rupees numbere was given to the appellant by Manmohan Anandji Mehta. There is also evidence that as a companysequence of the payment of money Manmohan Anandji Mehta did hire Kamal Govind for prostitution and it is regrettable to say that with the money given to him by the police he acted number merely as a bogus customer, as he has been described, but his participation was more active, reprehensible, immodest, indecent and indecorous. If in any case the following observations of Lord Goddard, Chief Justice, in Brannan, v. Peek 3 are apposite it is this case The companyrt observes with companycern and disapproval the fact that the police authority as Derby thought it right to send a police officer into a public house to companymit an offence.

On the findings of the High Court we are unable to companye to any other companyclusion but the one to which the High Court came that the appellant is guilty of the offences of which she was accused. The next submission of Counsel for the appellant was that the High Court in appeal companyld number order the appellants eviction because that power only a Magistrate has under s. 18 of the Act. The argument raised was that the powers of the appeal companyrt under s. 423, Criminal Procedure Code are to reverse the order of acquittal or to order a fresh enquiry or a retrial etc. but number to order eviction. But this argument is untenable in view of the fact that in the Act there is a specific provision in s. 18 of the Act authorising the making of such an order by a companyrt companyvicting a person of offences under s. 3 or s. 7 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: But this argument is untenable in view of the fact that in the Act there is a specific provision in s. 18 of the Act authorising the making of such an order by a companyrt companyvicting a person of offences under s. 3 or s. 7 of the Act. The relevant portion of s. 18 is as follows- S. 18 Closure of brothels and eviction of offenders from the premises,- 1 ,and if after hearing the person companycerned, the magistrate is satisfied that the houseor portion is being used as a brothel or for carrying on prostitution then the magistrate may pass orders- a directing eviction of the occupier within seven days of the passing of the order from the house A companyrt companyvicting a person of any offence under section 3 or section 7 may pass orders under sub-section 1 without further numberice to such person to show cause as required in that sub-section. The High Court ordered the companyviction of the appellant under s. 3 of the Act and therefore it had the power to order her eviction.

On the findings of the High Court we are unable to companye to any other companyclusion but the one to which the High Court came that the appellant is guilty of the offences of which she was accused. The next submission of Counsel for the appellant was that the High Court in appeal companyld number order the appellants eviction because that power only a Magistrate has under s. 18 of the Act. The argument raised was that the powers of the appeal companyrt under s. 423, Criminal Procedure Code are to reverse the order of acquittal or to order a fresh enquiry or a retrial etc. but number to order eviction. But this argument is untenable in view of the fact that in the Act there is a specific provision in s. 18 of the Act authorising the making of such an order by a companyrt companyvicting a person of offences under s. 3 or s. 7 of the Act.
